chapter.title: Using &nm;
chapter.para: &nm; is the ideal solution for laptops and other portable computers. It supports state-of-the-art encryption types and standards for network connections, including connections to 802.1X protected networks. 802.1X is the IEEE Standard for Local and Metropolitan Area Networks—Port-Based Network Access Control. With &nm;, you need not worry about configuring network interfaces and switching between wired or wireless networks when you are moving. &nm; can automatically connect to known wireless networks or manage several network connections in parallel—the fastest connection is then used as default. Furthermore, you can manually switch between available networks and manage your network connection using an applet in the system tray.
Instead of only one connection being active, multiple connections may be active at once. This enables you to unplug your laptop from an Ethernet and remain connected via a wireless connection.

section.title: Use Cases for &nm;
section.para: &nm; provides a sophisticated and intuitive user interface, which enables users to easily switch their network environment. However, &nm; is not a suitable solution in the following cases:

listitem.para: Your computer provides network services for other computers in your network, for example, it is a DHCP or DNS server.
Your computer is a &xen; server or your system is a virtual system inside Xen.

section.title: Enabling or Disabling &nm;
section.para: On laptop computers, &nm; is enabled by default. However, it can be at any time enabled or disabled in the &yast; Network Settings module.

step.para: Run &yast; and go to Network Devices Network Settings .
The Network Settings dialog opens. Go to the Global Options tab.
To configure and manage your network connections with &nm;:
In the Network Setup Method field, select User Controlled with &nm;.
Configure your network connections with &nm; as described in .
To deactivate &nm; and control the network in the traditional way:
In the Network Setup Method field, choose Traditional Method with ifup.
Set up your network card with &yast; using automatic configuration via DHCP or a static IP address. Alternatively, configure your modem with &yast;:

listitem.para: For dial-up connections, use Network Devices Modem .
To configure an internal or USB ISDN modem, select Network Devices ISDN .
To configure an internal or USB DSL modem, select Network Devices DSL .

section.title: Configuring Network Connections
section.para: After having enabled &nm; in &yast;, configure your network connections with the &nm; front-ends available in KDE and GNOME. The network configuration dialogs for both front-ends are very similar. They show tabs for all types of network connections, such as wired, wireless, mobile broadband, DSL, and VPN connections. On each tab, you can add, edit or delete connections of that type. In the KDE configuration dialog, the appropriate tabs are only active if the connection type is available on your system (depending on hardware and software). By default, K&nm; also displays comprehensive tool tips for the input fields and options available on each tab.

note.title: Bluetooth Connections
note.para: Currently, Bluetooth connections cannot be configured with &nm;.

section.para: To open the network configuration dialog in GNOME, open the main menu and click the Network entry at the right. Alternatively, press F2 and enter nm-connection-editor or select System Network Connections in the GNOME Control Center.
If you use KDE, open the main menu and click Configure Desktop. In the Personal Settings, select Network Settings (on the General tab) to open the network configuration dialog.

Alternatively, you can also start the configuration dialogs from the &nm; applet in the system tray. In KDE, left-click the icon and select Manage Connections. In GNOME, right-click the icon and select Edit Connections.

note.title: Availability of Options
note.para: Depending on your system set-up, you may not be allowed to configure connections. In a secured environment, some options might be locked or require &rootuser; permission. Ask your system administrator for details.

procedure.title: Adding or Editing Connections
procedure.para: When configuring network connections with &nm;, you can also define system connections that can be shared by all users. In contrast to user connections, system connections are made available right after &nm; is started—before any users log in. For more details about both types of connections, refer to .

note.title: Hidden Networks
note.para: To connect to a hidden network (a network that does not broadcast its service) you have to know the Service Set Identifier (SSID) or Extended Service Set Identifier (ESSID) of the network. Hidden networks cannot be detected automatically.

step.para: In the network configuration dialog, click the tab for the connection type you want to use.
Click Add to create a new connection or select an existing connection and click Edit.
Enter a Connection Name and your connection details.
For a hidden network, enter the ESSID and the encryption parameters.

You can tie the connection to a certain device, if more than one physical device per connection type is available (for example, your machine is equipped with two ethernet cards or two wireless cards).
If you use KDE, do so by using the Restrict to Interface option. If you use GNOME, enter the MAC address of the device you want to tie the connection to and confirm your settings.
For &nm; to automatically use a certain connection, activate the following option for this connection: Connect Automatically (KDE) or Stay connected when possible (GNOME).
To turn a connection into a system connection activate Available to all users (GNOME). To create and edit system connections, &rootuser; permission is required.

section.para: After having confirmed your changes, the newly configured network connection appears in the list of available networks you get by left-clicking the &nm; applet.

section.title: &nm; and VPN
section.para: &nm; supports several Virtual Private Network (VPN) technologies. For each technology, &productname; comes with a base package providing the generic support for &nm;. In addition to that, you also need to install the respective desktop-specific package for your applet.

listitem.para: To use this VPN technology, install
&nm;-novellvpn and
&nm;-novellvpn-kde4 or &nm;-novellvpn-gnome.
NovellVPN support for KDE is not available yet, but is currently being worked on.
To use this VPN technology, install
&nm;-openvpn and
&nm;-openvpn-kde4 or &nm;-openvpn-gnome.
To use this VPN technology, install
&nm;-vpnc and
&nm;-vpnc-kde4 or &nm;-vpnc-gnome.
To use this VPN technology, install
&nm;-pptp and
&nm;-pptp-kde4 or &nm;-pptp-gnome.

section.para: After you have installed the packages, configure your VPN connection as described in .

section.title: &nm; and Security
section.para: &nm; distinguishes two types of wireless connections, trusted and untrusted. A trusted connection is any network that you explicitly selected in the past. All others are untrusted. Trusted connections are identified by the name and MAC address of the access point. Using the MAC address ensures that you cannot use a different access point with the name of your trusted connection.

&nm; periodically scans for available wireless networks. If multiple trusted networks are found, the most recently used is automatically selected. &nm; waits for your selection in case that all networks are untrusted.

If the encryption setting changes but the name and MAC address remain the same, &nm; attempts to connect, but first you are asked to confirm the new encryption settings and provide any updates, such as a new key.
If you switch from using a wireless connection to offline mode, NetworkManager blanks the SSID or ESSID. This ensures that the card is disconnected.

section.title: User and System Connections
section.para: &nm; knows two types of connections: user and system connections. User connections are connections that become available to &nm; when the first user logs in. Any required credentials are asked from the user and when the user logs out, the connections are disconnected and removed from &nm;. Connections that are defined as system connection can be shared by all users and are made available right after &nm; is started—before any users log in. In case of system connections, all credentials must be provided at the time the connection is created. Such system connections can be used to automatically connect to networks that require authorization. For information how to configure user or system connections with &nm;, refer to .
For KDE, configuring system connections with &nm; are currently not supported (use &yast; instead).

section.title: Storing Passwords and Credentials
section.para: If you do not want to re-enter your credentials each time you want to connect to an encrypted network, you can use the desktop-specific tools GNOME Keyring Manager or KWalletManager to store your credentials encrypted on the disk, secured by a master password.

In KDE, you can configure if and how to store your credentials. To do so, left-click the &nm; icon and select Manage Connections. Click Other Connection Secrets and select one of the following options:

listitem.para: This is useful if you are working in an environment where storing credentials is considered a security risk.

If you choose this option, your passwords are stored unencrypted in the respective connection file that is created for each connection.
Find them under $HOME/.kde4/share/apps/networkmanagement/connections.

warning.title: Security Risk
warning.para: Storing your network credentials unencrypted is a security risk. Everybody who has access to your computer can reuse your connectivity and intercept your network connection.

listitem.para: If you choose this options, your credentials are stored in KWalletManager. For more information on KWalletManager, see .

section.para: &nm; can also retrieve its certificates for secure connections (for example, encrypted wired, wireless or VPN connections) from the certificate store. For more information, refer to .

section.title: Frequently Asked Questions
section.para: In the following, find some frequently asked questions about configuring special network options with &nm;.

varlistentry.term: How to tie a connection to a specific device?

listitem.para: By default, connections in &nm; are device type-specific: they apply to all physical devices with the same type. If more than one physical device per connection type is available (for example, your machine is equipped with two ethernet cards), you can tie a connection to a certain device.

To do so in GNOME, first look up the MAC address of your device (use the Connection Information available from the applet, or use the output of command line tools like nm-tool or ifconfig). Then start the dialog for configuring network connections and choose the connection you want to modify. On the Wired or Wireless tab, enter the MAC Address of the device and confirm your changes.

If you are using KDE, start the dialog for configuring network connections and choose the connection you want to modify. On the Ethernet or Wireless tab, use the Restrict to Interface option to select the network interface to which to tie the connection.

varlistentry.term: How to specify a certain access point in case multiple access points with the same ESSID are detected?

listitem.para: When multiple access points with different wireless bands (a/b/g/n) are available, the access point with the strongest signal is automatically chosen by default. To override this, use the BSSID field when configuring wireless connections.

The Basic Service Set Identifier (BSSID) uniquely identifies each Basic Service Set. In an infrastructure Basic Service Set, the BSSID is the MAC address of the wireless access point. In an independent (ad-hoc) Basic Service Set, the BSSID is a locally administered MAC address generated from a 46-bit random number.
Start the dialog for configuring network connections as described in . Choose the wireless connection you want to modify and click Edit. On the Wireless tab, enter the BSSID.

varlistentry.term: How to share network connections to other computers?

listitem.para: The primary device (the device which is connected to the Internet) does not need any special configuration. However, you need to configure the device that is connected to the local hub or machine as follows:

Start the dialog for configuring network connections as described in . Choose the connection you want to modify and click Edit. If you are using GNOME, switch to the IPv4 Settings tab and from the Method drop-down list, choose Shared to other computers. If you are using KDE, switch to the IP Address tab and from the Configure drop-down list, choose Shared. That will enable IP traffic forwarding and run a DHCP server on the device. Confirm your changes in &nm;.

As the DCHP server uses port 67, make sure that it is not blocked by the firewall: On the machine sharing the connections, start &yast; and select Security and Users Firewall . Switch to the Allowed Services category. If DCHP Server is not already shown as Allowed Service, select DCHP Server from Services to Allow and click Add. Confirm your changes in &yast;.

varlistentry.term: How to provide static DNS information with automatic (DHCP, PPP, VPN) addresses?

listitem.para: In case a DHCP server provides invalid DNS information (and/or routes), you can override it. Start the dialog for configuring network connections as described in . Choose the connection you want to modify and click Edit. If you are using GNOME, switch to the IPv4 Settings tab, and from the Method drop-down list, choose Automatic (DHCP) addresses only. If you are using KDE, switch to the IP Address tab, and from the Configure drop-down list, choose Automatic (DHCP) addresses only. Enter the DNS information in the DNS Servers and Search Domains fields. To Ignore automatically obtained routes click Routes (GNOME) and activate the respective check box, or from the drop-down list at the bottom of the tab (KDE), select Routes and activate the respective check box. Confirm your changes.

varlistentry.term: How to make &nm; connect to password protected networks before a user logs in?

listitem.para: Define a system connection that can be used for such purposes. For more information, refer to .

section.title: Troubleshooting

listitem.para: The GNOME and KDE &nm; applets start automatically if the network is set up for &nm; control. If the applet does not start, check if &nm; is enabled in &yast; as described in . Then make sure that the appropriate package for your desktop environment is also installed. If you are using KDE 4, the package is &nm;-kde4. For GNOME users the package is &nm;-gnome.

If the desktop applet is installed but is not running for some reason, start it manually. If the desktop applet is installed but is not running for some reason, start it manually with the command nm-applet (GNOME) or knetworkmanager (KDE).

varlistentry.term: &nm; Applet Does Not Include the VPN Option

listitem.para: Support for &nm;, applets, and VPN for &nm; is distributed in separate packages. If your &nm; applet does not include the VPN option, check if the packages with &nm; support for your VPN technology are installed. For more information, see .

If you have configured your network connection correctly and all other components for the network connection (router, etc.) are also up and running, it sometimes helps to restart the network interfaces on your computer. To do so, log in to a command line as &rootuser; and run rcnetwork restart.
